Using a variety of instruments, it will delve into the inside of the Mars surface, burying underneath.Elon Musk renames 'BFR' rocket to 'Starship'As it does, it will send back information about what the planet looks like underneath that famous, dusty red surface. Scientists hope to learn about not only Mars itself but also about other rocky planets in our own solar system – including Earth.The rover will land on the surface on Monday evening, UK time. Nasa will livestream the proceedings, and they will be covered as they happen here on&nbspThe Independent.That descent is not guaranteed, and comes amid concern and upset about the future of the Opportunity rover. There have been numerous failed missions to Mars: from the European Space Agency's&nbspSchiaparelli&nbsplander, which smashed into the surface in 2016 at such speed it could not have survived, all the way back to the original Soviet missions in the 1970s which repeatedly failed.This time around, we'll get to know if it's successful straight away. That's thanks to two little flying robots known as CubeSats – named WALL-E and EVE after the main characters in the 2008 animated film – which went to Mars on the same rocket that is carrying the new lander and will fly past the Red Planet, relaying messages about its progress to&nbspground controllers nearly 100 million miles away.Once the lander arrives on Mars, it will sit stationary and begin its work, looking deep underneath the surface for clues about what is going on there. TMA-11M capsule shortly after the spacecraft landed with Expedition 39 Commander Koichi Wakata of the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), Soyuz Commander Mikhail Tyurin of Roscosmos, and Flight Engineer Rick Mastracchio of NASA near the town of Zhezkazgan, Kazakhstan2930 Jupiter's Great Red Spot Viewed by Voyager I3030 Chandra Observatory Sees a Heart in the DarknessThe stationary probe, launched from California in May, will then pause for 16 minutes for the dust to settle around the landing site before its disc-shaped solar arrays unfurl to provide power.Engineers at Nasa’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) hope to get real-time electronic confirmation of the spacecraft’s safe arrival from miniature satellites launched along with InSight which will fly past Mars.Everything you need to know as Nasa lands on MarsThe JPL controllers also expect to receive a photo of the probe’s surroundings on the flat, smooth Martian plain close to the planet’s equator called the Elysium Planitia.The site is roughly 373 miles from the 2012 landing spot of the car-sized Mars rover Curiosity, the last spacecraft sent to the Red Planet by Nasa.The smaller, 880-pound (360kg) InSight – its name is short for Interior Exploration Using Seismic Investigations, Geodesy and Heat Transport – marks the 21st US-launched Martian exploration including the Mariner fly-by missions of the 1960s.Nearly two dozen other Mars missions have been sent from other nations.&nbspInSight is the first mission dedicated to unlocking secrets from deep below the Martian surface.The lander will spend 24 months – around one Martian year – using seismic monitoring and underground drilling to gather clues on how Mars formed and, by extension, the origins of Earth and other rocky planets of the inner solar system more than four&nbspbillion years ago.While Earth’s tectonics and other forces have erased most evidence of its early history, much of Mars – which is about one-third the size of Earth – is believed to have remained largely static over the eons, creating a geologic time machine for scientists.Nasa's InSight lander descending towards the surface of Mars on its giant parachute (NASAJPL-CaltechPA)InSight’s primary instrument is a highly sensitive French-built seismometer, designed to detect the slightest vibrations from “marsquakes” and meteor impacts.Scientists expect to see a dozen to 100 marsquakes over the course of the mission, producing data to help them deduce the size, density and composition of the planet.InSight about to land on the surface of the Red Planet (NASAJPL-CaltechPA)The Viking probes of the mid-1970s were equipped with seismometers, but they were bolted on top the landers, a design that proved largely ineffective.InSight&nbspis also&nbspfitted with a German-made drill to burrow as much as 16ft (5m) underground, pulling behind it a rope-like thermal probe to measure heat.InSight probing the Martian surface (EPANASA)Meanwhile, a radio transmitter will send signals back to Earth, tracking Mars’ subtle rotational wobble to reveal the size of the planet’s core and possibly whether it remains molten.The InSight and the agency’s next rover mission, along with others in the planning stage, are seen as precursors for eventual human exploration of Mars, Nasa officials have said.Additional reporting by agenciesShare your thoughts and Described by engineers as seven minutes of terror, that is a journey that more landers have failed to make than have succeeded.It comes at the end of a seven-month trip from Earth. And it has been many years in the planning, marking a new interest in journeying to our closest planet and the first time Nasa has arrived on Mars in six years.Everything happens about noon pacific, 3pm eastern, or 8pm in the UK.&nbspIf you're wanting to watch along, Nasa will be hosting live coverage on its TV channel. story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThe only thing anyone is going to be talking about is the head judge&nbspbeing thrown under the bus by technologyClick to followThe Independent CultureOn a Strictly night of great dances and a couple of shockingly low scores, the only thing anyone is going to be talking about is Shirley Ballas being thrown under the bus by a technical error. The moment in question madeher look incapable of reading aloud and saw co-presenter&nbspTess&nbspDaly silently stunned as the floor manager (presumably) fainted. &nbspUp until then, the most shocking moment of the night was one of this series’s favourites – former Pussycat Doll Ashley Roberts – only finishing third on the leaderboard.Here are the episode's five biggest talking points.There were many sniggers about how our seven remaining couples might crash into each other when they all took to the floor simultaneously to lindyhop the audience into submission. But in the end, it was the judges who provided the carnage. When the music stopped,&nbspBallas was asked to read out who came 7th. After a technical error meant her digital read out was unavailable, she reached for a scrap of paper and duly read out who had come first. Then she got the names of the professional dancers wrong. And was left to tie herself in knots before Claudia Winklemen eventually diffused the tension with a couple of one-liners. Seann&nbspand Katya will be furious they now have competition for the most awkward moment of the series.Faye and Giovanni’s dream waltzAshley and Pasha remain the only couple to receive a perfect 40 (translation: the only ones that&nbspCraig Revel-Horwood has given a ten), but Faye&nbspTozer and her partner, Giovanni, got really close tonight. They were nervous after abandoning their American Smooth to save Gio’s bad back mid-week, &nbspin favour of a waltz mid-week. But you couldn’t tell: it was a dreamy, graceful routine met with a shower of judges’ compliments. They finished top of the leaderboard and surely booked their place in next week’s quarter final.Stacey and Kevin’s fierce pasoStacey Dooley loved her Blackpool salsa so much she didn’t wash her hair for a week to preserve the memories. Watch her interview on Friday’s It Takes Two if you don’t believe me. After initially panicking about the ‘Paso Dooley’, she really attacked this number and Kevin choreographed an incredible routine to atmospheric, authentic music. After waiting all series for a ten they got three. See you in the final, Stace.Created with Sketch. story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the options'I now understand that the word has no place in any conversation'Click to followThe Independent CultureThe screenwriter of Shrek and Pirates of the Caribbean has apologised after using the N-word in a furious tweet.Tery Rossio issued a three-part statement that called the post a “mistake”, adding: “I now understand that the word has no place in any conversation, ever.”He continued: “You can’t make a point against hate speech and reference actual words of hate speech. That was insensitive and ignorant. A deeply felt apology to all.”In the original post, the Aladdin writer was comparing using the word to using the phrase “anti-vax”.He wrote the message in reply to Julie Benson, a writer on TV series The 100, who was calling for her users to contribute to vaccination efforts.Johnny Depp ‘dropped’ from Pirates of the CaribbeanHe replied: “My heart goes out to all the parents of vaccine damaged children, who have to not only endure the sadness of their loss, but also the vitriol of ill-informed and insensitive people (such as those here). Anti-Vax is equivalent to calling someone a n****r and makes as little sense.” &nbspAfter Benson replied asking Rossio to “...please never come on my feed with the N-word again,” Rossio replied: “Do you realise that you are using the equivalent of the ‘N-word’ in promoting memes that tag people as ‘anti-vax?’ Do you realize that the same collectivist stereotyping lies behind belittling any group with a label? title: the lion king remake trailer watched disney cast release date jon favreau
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThe trailer, which was revealed on Thanksgiving, generated 224.6 million global views in 24 hoursClick to followThe Independent CultureDisney has thanked its “entire pride” for making the trailer for a forthcoming remake of The Lion King&nbspits&nbspmost-watched trailer in a day, and the second most-viewed trailer debut from any studio in 24 hours.The trailer, which was revealed on Thanksgiving, generated 224.6 million global views in 24 hours, according to Disney studios, coming in second to the trailer for Avengers: Infinity War which attracted 238 million views.&nbspThe Lion King remake,&nbspfrom director Jon Favreau, with Donald Glover&nbspstarring as Simba and Beyonce&nbspas the voice of Nala, is slated&nbspfor release on 19 July 2019. Favreau previously had huge success with his remake of The Jungle Book, which grossed $966 million globally.Glover and Knowles-Carter are also joined by James Earl Jones, who reprises his role from the 1994 animated film as Simba's father Mufasa. Chiwetel Ejiofor will voice Simba's villainous uncle Scar, Alfre Woodard will star as Simba's mother Sarabi, and child actor JD McCrary will voice the young version of Simba.Everything we know about Disney's new Lion King remakeLion King trailer side-by-side with the original film is jaw droppingWatch the very first trailer for the new Lion King remakeShahadi Wright Joseph is voicing the young Nala, while John Kani voices the baboon Rafiki and John Oliver playing Mufasa’s confidant, Zazu. Elton John and Tim Rice, who won a Best Song Oscar for their original track Can You Feel the Love Tonight as part of their work on the original film, recently confirmed they have made a new end credits song for the remake.Some doubt has been expressed on social media by fans of the original film. Some have complained about the film being billed as a “live action” version rather than CGI. And while the casting generated considerable excitement, a viral video showing a shot-by-shot comparison of the new film’s opening with the original has prompted some fans to question whether anything different or new has been added.However, the majority reaction still appears to be largely positive, with much of the excitement focused on the all-star voice cast, and the obvious quality of the CGI in the film. &nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - “humble address” – the tactic Labour used to force the government to release Brexit economic assessments – to prevent it.Earlier, another senior Tory, Damian Collins – who opposes Ms May’s deal – said the public should be given the final say if it is rejected, in either a referendum or a general election.“I don't think, as parliament, we could just stand back and watch the country fall off the edge of a cliff without asking the people whether that was the step they wanted to take,” he said.Confirming he will vote against the agreement, Mr Collins said: “I don't accept that this is a deal we have to accept or face the cliff-edge.”Labour, which has vowed to stop the UK crashing out of the EU without a deal, welcomed Ms Rudd’s acknowledgement that parliament would hold the whip hand.“Amber Rudd seems to have ignored Number 10’s spin by admitting that Parliament would stop a no deal Brexit,” said Keir Starmer, the party’s Brexit spokesman.“It’s time for the government to drop the false choice British people, or my constituents, voted for in 2016.”Parliamentary private secretary to the ministry of justice Ranil Jayawardena resigned as he could not back the deal in good conscience“Because there’s no other proposition that can get through parliament.”Mr Blair said the deal failed&nbspto&nbsp”honour the Brexit mandate because the people who most fervently believe in Brexit say this isn’t Brexit”.“Therefore the only way you’re going to unite the county ultimately is to get this back to the people and say you’ve got a mandate, whether the government does a proper Brexit – that’s the sort of Brexit that Boris Johnson wants – or that we stay,” he said.Mr Blair pledged that “if the country votes again to Leave, I accept it and I’ll get behind it and try and make it work”.The Independent has launched a campaign for a Final Say referendum on Ms May’s Brexit deal, which has attracted more than a million supporters.However, shadow justice secretary Richard Burgon dismissed calls for a second referendum, saying Labour needed to focus on the upcoming Commons vote,&nbspwhich is expected on December 10 or 11, ahead of the next European Council meeting.Hunt admits it’s different Brexit’ if deal fails in CommonsTheresa May’s withdrawal deal endorsed by European Union- follow liveHe added: “We’re now reaching a point where Theresa May is trying to push through parliament an ill-fated, half-baked deal that’s the worst of all worlds.“We need to work as hard as we can to ensure she thinks again and try and bring people together on the basis of a deal that works in the national interest.”It comes after it emerged that John McDonnell, the shadow chancellor, had met with former Labour spin doctors Alastair Campbell and Tom Baldwin, who are senior figures from the People’s Vote campaign.Mr McDonnell told the Sunday Times:&nbsp“I was happy to meet representatives from the People’s Vote campaign simply to map out what options are available to us based on conference policy, which includes the option of a public vote.”Sources close to Mr McDonnell advised that Labour’s policy had not changed and&nbspthat he was still pushing for a general election.The title: brexit deal theresa may eu leaders approve summit
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThis is the only deal possible, says Jean-Claude JunckerClick to followIndy PoliticsEU leaders have approved Theresa May’s Brexit deal at a special summit in Brussels on Sunday, warning that it is “the only deal possible” within the prime minister’s red lines.The signoff by the bloc paves the way for MPs to vote on the deal, with officials in Brussels told to expect MPs to make their decision on 10 or 11 December.The 27 heads of state and government are understood to have avoided discussing what would happen if the deal was rejected by parliament, as now looks increasingly likely.EU officials given date for crunch Brexit vote in CommonsOfficials privy to the private top-level meeting said the plan was adopted in “a matter of seconds” with one describing the short session as “solemn”.Some EU chiefs gave emotional goodbyes to Britain, with council president Donald Tusk telling journalists: “Regardless of how it will all end, one thing is certain: we will remain friends until the end of days, and a day longer.”But commission president Jean-Claude Juncker struck a starker tone, warning: “This is the best deal possible for Britain, this is the best deal possible for Europe, this is the only deal possible. The only deal possible.”&nbspHe added: “Those who think that by rejecting the deal that they would have a better deal will be disappointed in the first seconds after the rejection of this deal.”Outside the summit, pro-Remain activists took a blowtorch to a mock copy of the withdrawal agreement, before they were asked to stop by Belgian police.EU president Juncker says he would vote in favour of May’s Brexit dealEU leaders agree to back Theresa May’s Brexit dealTop ministers ‘plotting different Brexit’ if deal fails in CommonsTheresa May writes ‘letter to nation’ insisting Brexit agreement worksHigh Court to rule if Brexit vote ‘void’ amid Banks investigationSpeaking on the doorstep of the meeting, Dutch prime minister Mark Rutte said he did not expect MPs to reject the deal.“I don’t expect a ‘no’ vote. I expect a ‘yes’ vote and this is the deal on the table. I don’t think there’s anything more,” he said.Discussion about what to do in the event the deal was rejected was notable by its absence from the meeting, with one senior EU official saying there was “no appetite” for it after the gruelling slog to an agreement.“I don’t think there were any ‘what if’ questions asked to Theresa May today, quite a few were wishing her good luck,” they said.We don’t want to create the false impression for the UK that a better alternative deal is possibleIrish prime minister Leo Varadkar said: “We made the conscious decision as 27 not to speculate&nbspon alternative scenarios.“We don’t want to create the false impression for the UK that a better alternative deal is possible.”Austrian chancellor Sebastian Kurz added: “It is important that everyone in the UK is aware of the fact that this agreement is the final result. It will definitely not be renegotiated and there will be no further leeway.”The European Council conclusions released after the meeting specifically thanked chief negotiator Michel Barnier “for his tireless efforts as the Union’s chief negotiator and for his contribution to maintaining the unity among EU27 member states throughout the negotiations”.&nbspEU leaders met among&nbspthemselves without Theresa May, and were then joined by the British prime minister to discuss the deal once they had signed it off. story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsFollow all the latest updates&nbspClick to followIndy PoliticsTheresa May today faces a showdown with MPs in the Commons as she attempts to gather support for her Brexit deal, warning them that voting down the deal risks the country going “back to square one”.It comes as the prime minister prepares to meet her cabinet ministers following the special EU council summit in Brussels on Sunday during which both the withdrawal agreement and political declaration for the future UK-EU relationship were agreed.Reports also emerged Ms May will challenge Jeremy Corbyn to a debate in the coming days over her Brexit deal which he has – on multiple occasions – said his party will vote down in the Commons.Corbyn says he would relish debate over Brexit with PMIndependent economic analysis of May's Brexit deal says average inidual&nbspwould be £1,000 worse off&nbspEU leaders approve May's deal, but say no to renegotiationAccording to Reuters, the German finance minister Olaf Scholz has said Brexit will hurt everyone involved, but added the deal sealed on Sunday at the special EU council lays the foundations for a good development.&nbspSir Keir Starmer, the shadow Brexit secretary, has also been on the airwaves this morning – claiming that if May’s Brexit deal fails to pass the Commons she could be sent back to Brussels to negotiate better terms.&nbspAsked if Parliament can stop the clock running out on getting an agreement and preventing such an outcome, he admitted any motion by MPs to try and do so might not be binding.&nbspHe told Radio 4's Today programme: If you had a vast majority saying we don't authorise the government to leave with no deal, it would be very difficult for the government politically to do so.&nbspI accept that may not be legally binding, there would then have to be legislation before March for any government preparing for no deal and there would be plenty of opportunities to put amendments down to that to require the government to do things.&nbspFor example, to extend Article 50. I accept that no deal is something that is going to have to involve the whole EU but I think there would be a very strong push by the majority in Parliament against no deal.&nbspI don't think this Prime Minister would simply plough on regardless, as she knows how dangerous no deal is.&nbspEuropean Commission president Jean-Claude Junker has insisted the deal reach on Monday between the UK and the EU is the “best deal for Britain” and “the only possible deal”.&nbspHe told Radio 4’s Today programme that if the House of Commons rejects the deal when asked to vote in the coming weeks, “we would have no deal”.&nbspHe added: It's not the intention of the Prime Minister, the Cabinet, nor of the Parliament, to go for a second referendum. This is the deal.&nbspAsked if the Brexit negotiation was a punishment process for the UK, Mr Juncker said: I don't understand why the British people, and I like the British people for so many including historical reasons, why they are feeling that they are humiliated.&nbspI don't see that because numerous points of view of the British have been taken into this deal. So, this is not a humiliation for Britain.Stephen Barclay - the new Brexit secretary - has admitted it will be a challenge to get May's deal through parliament as scores of MPs say they will vote against it.But he told BBC Radio 4's Today the PM&nbsphas got the best agreement possible for the UK&nbspafter her negotiations with Brussels.Asked about how the government will get the deal secured by Ms May at yesterday's summit approved by the House of Commons, Mr Barclay said: Well it's going to be a challenging vote.But it's now the job of all of us in Cabinet to make the case to our colleagues, to make the case to the country.The Prime Minister, after two years working day and night in the national interest, has secured a deal that respects the referendum result. story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsPrime minister planning campaign to take case for her deal to the nationClick to followIndy PoliticsJeremy Corbyn has said he “would relish” a head-to-head TV debate with Theresa May as the prime minister embarks on a campaign to sell her Brexit deal to the nation.Ms May will attempt to drum up support for her withdrawal agreement – approved by EU leaders on Sunday – while hoping to overcome huge opposition to it in the Commons ahead of MPs’ “meaningful vote” in December.She will warn MPs that rejecting her plan will&nbsp“open the door to more ision and uncertainty, with all the risks that will entail”. Reports suggested she would seek a TV debate with Mr Corbyn as part of that campaign.Responding to those&nbspreports, a Labour spokesperson said on Sunday night: “Jeremy would relish a head to head debate with Theresa May about her botched Brexit deal and the future of our country.”EU leaders approve Theresa May’s Brexit but say it cannot be changedMr Corbyn has said the deal represents&nbsp”the result of a miserable failure of negotiation that leaves us with the worst of all worlds”.Nicola Sturgeon, the Scottish first minister, had already thrown&nbspher hat in the ring. She tweeted on&nbspSaturday: “I’d be up for a full leaders debate on the ‘deal’.”Ms May is due to face the Commons again now that her plan has won EU approval, and is expected to tell parliamentary colleagues: “Our duty as a parliament over these coming weeks is to examine this deal in detail, to debate it respectfully, to listen to our constituents and decide what is in our national interest.“There is a choice which MPs will have to make. We can back this deal, deliver on the vote of the referendum and move on to building a brighter future of opportunity and prosperity for all our people.“Or this house can choose to reject this deal and go back to square one.”Created with Sketch. The act of remembrance blurs with the ethics of 21st century environmentalismA tent pitched in the middle of the city, next to the pavement, cramped in a corner. story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsSarcophagus is one two found in burial site of nobles and senior officials close to the pharaohs on western bank of the Nile&nbspClick to followThe IndependentArchaeologists remove the cover of an intact sarcophagus inside a tomb in Luxor, Egypt A well-preserved mummy of a woman inside an unopened coffin dating back more than 3,000 years has been unveiled in the southern Egyptian city of Luxor.The sarcophagus was one of two found earlier this month by a French-led mission in the northern area of El-Asasef necropolis on the western bank of the Nile.The first one had been opened earlier and examined by Egyptian antiquities officials,&nbspbut the unveiling of the second on Saturday was the first time authorities had opened a previously unopened sarcophagus before international media.AFPGetty)Egypt’s minister of antiquities,&nbspKhaled&nbspAl&nbspAnani,&nbspsaid:&nbsp“One sarcophagus was rishi-style, which dates back to the 17th dynasty, while the other sarcophagus was from the 18th dynasty.&nbsp“The two tombs were present with their mummies inside.”The 18th&nbspdynasty dates back to the 13th century BC, a period noted for some of the most well-known pharaohs, including Tutankhamen and Ramses II.Abd El Ghany)Located between the royal tombs at the Valley of the Queens and the Valley of the Kings, the El-Asasef&nbspnecropolis is the burial site of nobles and senior officials close to the pharaohs.The tomb belonged to Thaw-Irkhet-If, the mummification supervisor at the Temple of Mut in Karnak, according to the ministry.Among the finds in the tomb were five coloured masks and around 1,000 Ushabti statutes – the miniature figurine of servants to serve the dead in the afterlife.Three hundred cubic meters of rubble were removed over five months to uncover the tomb, which contained coloured ceiling paintings depicting the owner and his family.Egypt has revealed over a dozen ancient discoveries since the beginning of this year. The country hopes these discoveries will brighten its image abroad and revive interest among travellers who once flocked to its iconic pharaonic temples and pyramids but who have shunned the country since its 2011 political uprising.&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: brexit news latest deal today uk eu theresa may withdrawal agreement
story: In a stark message, the Prime Minister is expected to tell the Commons that people around the country have had enough of the political infighting over her deal with Brussels and want the issue concluded as soon as possible. I believe our national interest is clear, she will tell MPs. &ldquoThe British people want us to get on with a deal that honours the referendum and allows us to come together again as a country whichever way we voted.                EU has secret plan to extend Article 50 amid fears over May's deal                Police forced to stop anti-Brexit protester sets fire to Brexit dealHer remarks come ahead of the crunch Commons vote on her Brexit deal that was endorsed by EU leaders at a summit in Brussels yesterday.Downing Street sources have told the  the historic vote will be held on December 12 following five full days of Commons debate.In a statement reporting on yesterday's summit, the Prime Minister will tell MPs today: Our duty - as a Parliament over these coming weeks - is to examine this deal in detail, to debate it respectfully, to listen to our constituents and decide what is in our national interest.&ldquoThere is a choice which MPs will have to make.&ldquoWe can back this deal, deliver on the vote of the referendum and move on to building a brighter future of opportunity and prosperity for all our people.&ldquoOr this House can choose to reject this deal and go back to square one.It would open the door to more ision and more uncertainty, with all the risks that will entail.British Prime Minister Theresa May (Image: Sean GallupGetty Images)Mrs May will warn that the EU has given the UK a take-it-or-leave without a deal offer, saying: I can say to the House with absolute certainty that there is not a better deal available.She will add: I believe our national interest is clear.&ldquoThe British people want us to get on with a deal that honours the referendum and allows us to come together again as a country whichever way we voted.&ldquoThis is that deal. A deal that delivers for the British people.Leaders of the 27 nations remaining in the EU after Britain leaves took just 38 minutes to rubber stamp the draft Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration on the UK's future relationship with the EU at a special summit in Brussels.At the gathering called to conclude 18 months of Brexit negotiations, a string of leaders said Parliament had to accept the deal on the table as no better alternative would be offered.                Labour's secret talks with People&rsquos Vote backing SECOND REFERENDUM                Brexit news: May will revive THIS EU offer if Parliament rejects dealPresident of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker  (Image: Sean GallupGetty Images)European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said: This is the deal. It's the best deal possible and the EU will not change its fundamental position when it comes to these issues, he said.Those who think by rejecting the deal that they would have a better deal will be disappointed in the first seconds after the rejection of this deal.Dutch prime minister Mark Rutte added: This is the deal on the table. I don't think there is anything more now.Mrs May yesterday acknowledged she faced a massive challenge to persuade MPs to back her deal in the run up to the vote. Five days of intense and rancorous Commons debates are expected in the run up to the crucial ision.It will be one of the most significant votes that Parliament has held for many years, the Prime Minister said at a news conference at the end of the Brussels summit yesterday.On it will depend whether we move forward together into a brighter future or open the door to yet more ision and uncertainty, she said.I will take this deal back to the House of Commons, confident we have achieved the best deal available and full of optimism about the future of our country.Mrs May yesterday acknowledged she faced a massive challenge to persuade MPs to back her deal (Image: )In Parliament and beyond it, I will make the case for this deal with all my heart and I look forward to that campaign.She added: The British people don't want to spend any more time arguing about Brexit.They want a good deal done that fulfils the vote and allows us to come together again as a country.Mrs May refused to be drawn on whether she would stand down if she lost the vote, despite being repeatedly pressed during her end of summit press conference.I am focusing on ensuring that I make a case for this deal to MPs, she said.Mrs May also admitted she did not share the sadness expressed by German Chancellor Angela Merkel after the UK's exit from the EU.Asked if she felt sad, the Prime Minister said: No, but I recognise that others do. I recognise some European leaders are sad at this moment.But also some people back home in the UK are sad at this moment.Mrs May refused to be drawn on whether she would stand down if she lost the vote (Image: PHILIPPE LOPEZAFPGetty Images)The way Iook at it is that it's for us now to move on to the next stage.I'm full of optimism about the future of our country. I believe that we can with this good deal with the EU we will remain friends and neighbours.We are leaving the EU but we are not leaving Europe. We will continue to have that good, close partnership and relationship with countries within the EU.During her press conference, Mrs May said: I believe there should not be that second referendum, we gave the choice to the British people, they voted, they voted to leave the EU, I think we should now deliver on that.She added: They'd (the public) expect Parliament to vote on the deal as it is presented.Asked if she would stand down if the deal is voted down in the Commons, she replied: I am focusing on ensuring that I make a case for this deal to MPs and I think the point that Jean-Claude Juncker was making, that's been reiterated by others was that if people think somehow there's another negotiation to be done that's not the case.This is a deal that's the result of what has been tough and difficult negotiations over a significant period of time and as has been said this is the deal that's on the table, this is the best possible deal, it's the only possible deal.By yesterday, more than 90 Tory MPs had publicly threatened to vote against Mrs May's deal.Former Cabinet minister Iain Duncan Smith, who Downing Street aides had hoped to win over, yesterday said it would be very, very difficult to support the Prime Minister's deal arguing far too much has been given to the EU.He told Sky News's Sophy Ridge on Sunday: Well I don't want to stay in the EU. I campaigned and voted to leave the EU. I don't believe that, so far, this deal delivers on what the British people really voted for, take back control of your borders, your laws, your money. I think it has ceded too much control.In another blow to the Prime Minister, former Tory leader Lord Howard also joined the ranks of those opposing her deal yesterday.It's not a deal I can support.It's not a deal that is a good deal for the UK in several respects, but the one sticking point that I have relates to the arrangements for leaving the backstop, he said.The Prime Minister gathered her cabinet together ahead of a crunch Brexit showdown at her country retreat at Chequers in Buckinghamshire                    PA1 of 14Members of the cabinet and government officials gather at ChequersAs members of the European Union we had a unilateral, untrammelled right to leave under Article 50 which we are exercising.Under the backstop arrangements we could only leave with the permission of the European Union.That seems to me to be an absolute negation of taking control, that would put us in a worse position than we are now.And a senior Labour MP yesterday dampened the hopes of Tory whips that a significant number of opposition MPs in Leave-voting regions of the country could be won over to back the deal.Backbencher Lisa Nandy said: There's been no attempt to reach out to Labour MPs like me.It's just too big a gamble for MPs like me to take with our constituents' futures.Asked if she would be supporting the deal, she said: Well I'd hoped that it would be, but in all honesty no it's not and it's inconceivable now that when this comes before Parliament in just a few days&rsquo time that I'll be voting for it. I won't be voting to support the Withdrawal Agreement.

story: Ireland&rsquos Prime Minister today warned there was no &ldquoplan B after the 27 EU member states agreed the draft withdrawal text at a special meeting of the EU Council in Brussels. Ireland&rsquos leader said: There isn't a plan B. What's being put in front of EU parliament and House of Commons is a deal. Any other deal really only exists in people's imagination.                Police forced to stop anti-Brexit protester sets fire to Brexit deal                Theresa May looks EVER MORE likely to be taking UK towards no-dealMr Varadkar added that the agreement was the &ldquobest deal for the UK.He said: &ldquoThe truth is what we have here is the best deal that is available both for the United Kingdom and for the European Union.Let's not forget what we have here. We have an agreement that took between 18 months and two years to negotiate, it is in several parts, is over 500 pages long and as of today has the support of 28 governments.Anyone can have a better deal or an alternative deal in their own minds, but an agreement 500 pages long that 28 member states can sign up to, nobody has that.Leo Varadkar warned there was no &ldquoplan B for Brexit (Image: )Mr Varadkar, pictured in Brussels, has ridiculed Brexiteers over their &ldquoimaginary Brexit plans (Image: )What's on the table is the only deal that's on the table.It comes as Theresa May travelled to Brussels for the summit today, marking an end to the UK&rsquos Brexit withdrawal negotiations with the bloc.It took just 40 minutes for EU leaders to approve the draft deal at the special meeting.However it is just the end of the beginning for Mrs May, who must win over MPs to vote the deal through Parliament, before the UK gets to work on future partnership talks. It's the best deal possible and the EU will not change its fundamental position when it comes to these issues.Those who think by rejecting the deal that they would have a better deal will be disappointed in the first seconds after the rejection of this deal.Mrs May is bracing for a major battle to push her unpopular Brexit deal through the House of Commons before Christmas. Theresa May travelled to Brussels for the summit (Image: )The deal has forged an unlikely alliance between Brexiteers and Remainers, with both camps slamming the draft agreement.More than 80 Tory rebels have publicly vowed to vote against the plan, while Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn revealed his party would not support the agreement, branding it a &ldquobad deal for the UK.And DUP leader Arlene Foster said she could not support the provisions on the Northern Ireland backstop.But the Prime Minister is determined the agreement is the best deal for the country.Mrs May said: The British people don't want to spend any more time arguing about Brexit. They want a good deal done that fulfils the vote and allows us to come together again as a country.I will take this deal back to the House of Commons, confident we have achieved the best deal available and full of optimism about the future of our country.In Parliament and beyond it, I will make the case for this deal with all my heart and I look forward to that campaign.

story: In a television interview, the Foreign Secretary acknowledged that no one could predict what would happen in the aftermath of a defeat for ministers in the so-called meaningful vote on the outcome of the Brussels negotiations to be held in the Commons next month. Asked directly if the Government could be brought down, he said: &ldquoIt&rsquos not possible to rule out anything, and that&rsquos why all of us have to say, what do your constituents actually want in this situation, and we have to work out what&rsquos in the national interest, and it&rsquos all about the balance of risks. This isn&rsquot a perfect deal for everyone, but does have a lot of what everyone wants.                Labour MP DODGES question after being asked if he would back PM CorbynMr Hunt gave his franks assessment of the task facing ministers in an interview on the BBC1 Andrew Marr show this morning.He also admitted the apparent strength of opposition to the deal across the Commons meant the vote was looking challenging but a lot can change over the next two weeks.He added: The thing people wouldn't forgive us for is if we got to 30th March next year and we hadn't left the EU or we hadn't put ourselves on a course to end free movement of people, which is the thing that mattered to most people, and so that's the uncertainty that we'd be risking.Mr Hunt, who voted Remain the 2016 EU referendum, also refused to say Britain would be better off under Mrs May's deal than staying in the EU.This deal as it stands mitigates most of the negative impacts, he said, adding: I think we will not be significantly worse off or better off, but what it does mean is that we get our independence back.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt arrives at 10 Downing Street on November 13 (Image: Leon NealGetty Images)                Theresa May &lsquowill FAIL&rsquo to seal immigration curbs in time to win vote                Brexit deal latest: What will happen if UK Parliament REJECTS deal?British Prime Minister Theresa May departs after speaking at a press conference in Brussels today (Image: Sean GallupGetty Images)It's for MPs now, of course, to scrutinise this properly but if that does not happen then, effectively, you will be back to square one with more uncertainty, more ision, he told the Sky News Sophy Ridge on Sunday show.It is important for people to get behind the Prime Minister, get behind the deal that we see being approved today, allowing us to move forward as a country on to all of those things that the British people want us to do, all of the domestic priorities.There was a clear message from people of let's get on with it, he said.Asked if the deal was better than EU membership he said: It does give effect to the vote of the British people and therefore, yes, I think it is now - things have now changed, we have had that referendum, we look towards a future outside of the European Union.

story: The Prime Minister wants to use a TV debate with Mr Corbyn as a political showpiece to seek the nation&rsquos endorsement, according to a newspaper report. A so-called &ldquomeaningful vote on her deal is planned to take place on December 12. Mrs May will announce on Monday plans for a media blitz to bring MPs into line.                90 Tories vow to vote against May's deal                EU FURIOUS at Spain&rsquos &lsquoOUTRAGEOUS&rsquo demands on Gibraltar The Labour leader &ldquowould relish the opportunity to take on Theresa May over her &ldquobotched Brexit in the proposed debate, his party has said.In response to the Daily  report citing Mrs May&rsquos desire to hold a debate, a Labour spokesman said: &ldquoJeremy would relish a head-to-head debate with Theresa May about her botched Brexit deal and the future of our country.In Brussels on Sunday the Prime Minister managed to convince EU leaders to rubber stamp her withdrawal agreement and political declaration for the UK&rsquos future relationship with the bloc.The political declaration is, however, not legally binding and is subject to change as the UK enters crucial negotiations with the 27 nations after its departure on March 29 2019.Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn could go head-to-head in a TV debate (Image: )Mrs May in Brussels on Sunday (Image: )Despite Mrs May&rsquos deal being publicly backed by EU leaders, the biggest challenge she faces is to get it through Parliament.More than 90 Tories - as well as the DUP and Labour - have said they will vote against the deal.Mrs May currently has a precarious majority of 13, with the DUP propping her Government up in a so-called &ldquoconfidence and supply deal.The DUP&rsquos leader, Arlene Foster, yesterday warned on the BBC&rsquos Andrew Marr Show her party could not feasibly vote for the deal in its current form.                 Brexit negotiator to make bid to REPLACE Juncker                Why European Parliament President Tajani wore red lipstick for Brex...The Prime Minister said it was her deal or risk no Brexit at all (Image: )With the current number of MPs threatening to vote down the deal, the Prime Minister has turned to other means to get the support she desperately needs.On Sunday she appealed to the nation in the form of an open letter, in which she said of her deal: &ldquoIt will be a deal that is in our national interest - one that works for our whole country and all of our people, whether you voted 'Leave' or 'Remain'.&ldquoIt will honour the result of the referendum.Speaking in Brussels on Sunday she implored voters to back her, saying: &ldquoIn Parliament and beyond it, I will make the case for this deal with all my heart, and I look forward to that campaign.In another development, insiders revealed Mrs May wants to hold a primetime Sunday night TV debate with Mr Corbyn ahead of Parliament&rsquos &ldquomeaningful vote.One senior aide admitted it will appear like a &ldquomini-election campaign adding: &ldquoThe Cabinet and the Prime Minister will be taking the message around all four corners of the United Kingdom over the period of the campaign.Jean Claude-Juncker spoke to the BBC about Theresa May's deal (Image: BBC)&ldquoIt will be taking the message to the party, the country and MPs.A No 10 official said &ldquonothing has been decided yet.Downing Street plans for the Prime Minister to deliver a major speech on December 11, the day before the vote.The vote&rsquos timing means Mrs May will be able to return to Brussels the day after and call on EU leaders to reiterate a message set out on Sunday: this is the only deal and the only alternative is &ldquono Brexit at all.In the Prime Minister&rsquos words: &ldquoThis is the deal that&rsquos on the table, it&rsquos the best possible deal, it&rsquos the only possible deal.President of the European Commission, Jean Claude-Juncker, concurred with Mrs May on Sunday, arguing the Brexit deal drafted by Mrs May is &ldquothe best deal possible for Britain.Speaking to the BBC, he said: &ldquoThis is the deal, this is the deal.The Luxembourger added: &ldquoI&rsquom never changing my mind.

story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are expected to move from Kensington Palace into their new place in the spring, after being given the residency by the Queen. Before then, some serious changes must be made as the 19th century building has fallen into &ldquodisrepair. A planning application has been lodged with the council for the Grade II-listed building that was previously used to house members of the Royal staff.                Royal PET PEEVES: One word the Queen HATES - and it's about Meghan                The FOUR things Kate carries in her handbag However, security concerns mean the plans have been kept private.A &ldquospecial note on the application states it contains &ldquosensitive information and the usual plans, architects drawings and others documents are not available for the public to access.This secrecy includes the cost of the building work, which is expected to involve multi-million pounds worth of renovations.A Kensington Palace spokesman said any substantial building work would be paid for through the Sovereign Grant, which is the amount of money the monarch receives from the Crown Estate - the rest goes to the Government.Meghan and Harry will be moving into their new home next year (Image: )Meghan and Harry announcing their engagement (Image: )The Royal couple hope to turn Frogmore Cottage into a five-bedroom family home, with space for a nursery and a live-in nanny, according to the Daily Mail.Decorative work inside their new cottage is expected to be paid for by Harry and Meghan.They currently live in two-bedroom Nottingham Cottage at Kensington Palace, near the home of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.Meghan, 37, and Harry, 34 are expecting their first child in April.                Meghan and Harry moving to Frogmore so mum Doria can help with baby                 Why did Prince Harry tell Meghan Markle not to do THIS with the Queen?The Duke and Duchess of Sussex during their Royal tour of Australia and New Zealand (Image: )Similar secrecy shrouded renovation plans at Anmer Hall in Norfolk before the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge moved into the Georgian manor on Sandringham Estate.Frogmore Cottage is on the Frogmore Estate near Frogmore House, where the couple held their wedding reception six months ago.The newlyweds also had their engagement pictures in the grounds.Frogmore is less than half a mile from Windsor Castle, meaning the Royal baby&rsquos great-grandmother, the Queen, would be living close by.Planning permission has already been approved to refit the cottage and install two &lsquoorangery&rsquo extensions.Frogmore House (Image: )Approved in July, the plans also allow for a bedroom to be built above the studio in the grounds of the cottage.A further planning application was submitted in October, which has yet to be approved.All that is known is that permission is sought for internal and external works at the cottage and &ldquolandscaping in the grounds.A note on the file states: &ldquoThe application contains sensitive information and therefore the public register is not accompanied by any forms, drawings or supporting documents.&ldquoThe application will be advertised in the usual way but there is no additional information that is publicly disclosable.

title: Brexit latest news theresa may brussels eu latest brexit deal
story: It took just 40 minutes to ratify nearly 600 pages of legal text and a 20-page roadmap for the EU's future relationship with Britain. And the response from Germany was lukewarm with politicians from Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democrat (CDU) party welcoming the deal with the UK while criticising Brexit itself. Senior CDU MEP David McAllister branded Brexit an historic mistake with heavy consequences for the UK.                May REBUKES Spanish claims of victory after last-minute Brexit deal                Brexit news: Gibraltar hits out at Pedro Sanchez to SNATCH the RockCDU parliamentary deputy leader Katja Leikert described the draft Withdrawal Agreement as the best possible result under very difficult circumstances.She said: There could be no perfect solution for Brexit, which is a fundamentally wrong decision, in our opinion.Social Democrat (SPD) politician Christian Petry said the Brexit deal endorsed in Brussels today would enable an &ldquoorderly withdrawal for the UK.But Greens' Europe spokeswoman Franziska Brantner said the deal was far too weak on the environment and social welfare and warned there was a risk of the UK undermining EU standards in those areas.Scroll down for live updates:Brexit latest: Prime Minister Theresa May has spoken to the media in Brussels  (Image: SKY)10.30pm update: May challenges MPs to back her Brexit planTheresa May will challenge MPs to back her Brexit plan or risk crashing out of the EU without an agreement.The Prime Minister will face the Commons after EU leaders endorsed the deal and made it clear it was not up for renegotiation.She will tell MPs with absolute certainty that there is not a better deal available.Mrs May, who chairs a Cabinet meeting tomorrw morning, will warn rejecting her deal will open the door to more ision and uncertainty, with all the risks that will entail.She will tell MPs: Our duty as a Parliament over these coming weeks is to examine this deal in detail, to debate it respectfully, to listen to our constituents and decide what is in our national interest.There is a choice which MPs will have to make. We can back this deal, deliver on the vote of the referendum and move on to building a brighter future of opportunity and prosperity for all our people.Or this House can choose to reject this deal and go back to square one ... It would open the door to more ision and more uncertainty, with all the risks that will entail.She will say that the national interest is clear and the British people want us to get on with a deal that honours the referendum.Boris Johnson has described the Brexit deal as a 'humiliation' (Image: )9.29pm update: Boris Johnson says Britain humiliated by Brexit dealFormer foreign secretary Boris Johnson has branded the Brexit deal a disaster and a humiliation for the UK.In his regular Daily  column, he said: The other EU countries have signed the deal immediately, because they know that they have us exactly where they want us.&ldquoWe are a satellite state - a memento mori fixed on the walls of Brussels as a ghastly gaping warning to all who try to escape.Restating his calls for the backstop to be scrapped, the full payment of &pound39 billion to be withheld until a trade deal is done, and intensified planning for a no-deal Brexit, Mr Johnson said: We cannot go on any more with this hopeless can't-do spirit this reflexive negativity and defeatism that so woefully underestimates the courage and creativity of the British people.Yes, there will be some logistical and technical challenges, and yes they will require some effort.But it is disgraceful that the Government is - deliberately - allowing those short-term challenges so to dominate the debate that we are ready to consign ourselves to decades as the impotent captive of the EU's over-taxed, badly regulated, low-growth economic model.7.30pm update: MPs criticise new Tory Twitter campaign to #BackTheBrexitDealBrexiteer MP Conor Burns said at least one loyal MP said a social media campaign to promote Theresa May&rsquos Brexit deal was a &ldquodreadful idea that must &ldquoeat at their soul.Cabinet ministers and loyal MPs joined Downing Street&rsquos social media campaign in support of Theresa May's Brexit deal, using the Twitter hashtag #BackTheBrexitDeal.The Government launched the campaign with a video selling the benefits of the deal to the public.The campaign comes after Prime Minister Theresa May wrote a letter to Britain asking them to back her Brexit deal.Chancellor Philip Hammond said the deal endorsed by EU leaders in Brussels will provide certainty for business.Business Secretary Greg Clark said firms needed an agreement not the disorder of no deal.Justice Secretary David Gauke said the deal was pragmatic, and new Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd said it was sensible in their supportive tweets.Environment Secretary Michael Gove retweeted supportive comments - but did not add his own &poundBackTheBrexitDeal remark.However there are yet to be comments of support from Brexiteers International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt or Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom.6.46pm update: Brussels bosses plan to extend Article 50Officials in Brussels have kickstarted plans to extend Britain&rsquos stay in the EU amid fears Theresa May&rsquos controversial Brexit deal will be rejected by rebellious MPs in the Commons.Secret plans to extend Article 50 are underway after senior EU figures warned Brexiteers and Remainers the Prime Minister&rsquos deal was non-negotiable after being rubber-stamped by leaders.The fresh manoeuvres come amid growing concerns that Mrs May will struggle to convince enough MPs to support the deal when it is put to Parliament in a so-called &ldquoMeaningful Vote in December.One EU senior official conceded extending the two-year Article 50 period would only benefit both sides preparations for a no-deal scenario.5.21pm update: Business leader calls on MPs to back May&rsquos agreementThere's more relief among businesses about today's agreement - and a warning to MPs.The head of the EEF manufacturer&rsquos association said the uncertainty had hit firms within the section particularly hard with delays in investment, job cuts and growth hit.Stephen Phipson said: &ldquoToday&rsquos agreement finally provides a clear pathway to a stable and sensible transition from full membership of the EU and avoids the horrific consequences of leaving without a deal.&ldquoWhich is why MPs should take note as the vote in Parliament approaches.I would strongly advise all MPs to look closely at this deal, the consequences of the alternative and make a pragmatic decision that provides our economy and business with the clarity and certainty we need.4.50pm update: Polish leader backs Brexit dealPolish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki has said the Brexit deal agreed by EU leaders today guarantees the rights of Poles in the UK, the interest of Polish companies and the EU budget.And he pledged that Poland and Britain would will remain close allies once the UK had left the EU.Around one million Polish nationals live in the UK and form the largest group of British residents born outside the country.3.45pm update: No &lsquoplan B&rsquo for Brexit dealLeo Varadkar has stated there is no &ldquoplan B and Theresa May&rsquos deal is the best deal on the table.The Taoiseach said: There isn't a plan B. The truth is what we have here is the best deal that is available both for the United Kingdom and for the European Union.He added that people should not be looking for alternative options - unlike Jeremy Corbyn who has stated he will not support the deal.Mr Varadkar added: Let's not forget what we have here. We have an agreement that took between 18 months and two years to negotiate, it is in several parts, is over 500 pages long and as of today has the support of 28 governments.Anyone can have a better deal or an alternative deal in their own minds, but an agreement 500 pages long that 28 member states can sign up to, nobody has that.What's on the table is the only deal that's on the table.2.30pm update: Brexit deal is &lsquonext best&rsquo option - VaradkarIreland's premier said the best outcome for all concerned would be if the UK remained in the EU, but given that was not going to happen the draft agreement was the next best option.Leo Varadkar said: &ldquoI've always thought the best outcome for Ireland and for Europe and indeed the United Kingdom would be for the UK to stay in the European Union, the customs union and the single market, but we respect the decision of the British people and the UK parliament not to do that.What we have agreed today is the next best outcome. It protects the peace, affirms the rights and freedoms of European, Irish and British citizens, ensures there will be no hard border and also insulates our economy from major disruptions in trade.He added: What we need to do now is to get on with it and get on with the ratification of this agreement by the House of Commons and also by the European Parliament and when that's done, from March, April onwards, to get busy negotiating the future relationship treaty.2.06pm update: Spain hints at new bid for Gibraltar sovereigntySpain has signalled it is preparing a fresh push over the sovereignty of Gibraltar as the Brexit talks enter a new phase of negotiations.Spanish prime minister Pedro Sanchez claimed the Withdrawal Agreement, signed off by EU leaders in Brussels on Sunday, represented a win for his country in the 300-year-old dispute over the Rock.He told an end-of-summit press conference: With the departure of the UK we all lose, especially the UK. But in relation to Gibraltar, Spain wins, and Europe wins.Mr Sanchez had earlier threatened to scupper the special summit to approve the deal unless he received fresh assurances on the status of the Rock in the forthcoming talks on a free trade deal between Britain and the EU.The Spanish leader was pressing for Madrid to have a veto over how any UK-EU trade deal applies to Gibraltar.In an effort to resolve the row, the UK's ambassador to the EU Sir Tim Barrow issued a letter on Saturday confirming the Withdrawal Agreement imposed no obligations regarding the territorial scope of future agreements.Theresa May again insisted that it made no difference to constitutional status of the Rock.1.00pm update: &lsquoWorst of all worlds&rsquo Corbyn confirms Labour will oppose Brexit deal.Jeremy Corbyn has confirmed Labour will vote against Theresa May&rsquos Brexit deal when MP&rsquos have their say in the House of Commons.The Labour leader said: This is a bad deal for the country.It is the result of a miserable failure of negotiation that leaves us with the worst of all worlds. It gives us less say over our future, and puts jobs and living standards at risk.That is why Labour will oppose this deal in Parliament. We will work with others to block a no-deal outcome, and ensure that Labour's alternative plan for a sensible deal to bring the country together is on the table.That includes a permanent customs union with a UK say, a strong single-market deal and guarantees on workers' rights, consumer and environmental protections.Theresa May's Government has started a Twitter campaign to #BackTheBrexitDeal (Image: )12.30pm update: PM confident the UK has achieved the &ldquobest dealTheresa May confident we have achieved the best deal for the UK as the EU endorsed the Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration on the future EU-UK relationship.The Prime Minister said the deal delivered for the British people and set the UK on course for a prosperous future.Mrs May also echoed comments made by the EU that this was the &ldquoonly deal possible.Addressing the media at a press conference in Brussels Mrs May said she will back her deal with all my heart as she faces an uphill battle to convince MP&rsquos to vote for her Brexit, which she confirmed will be before Christmas.The Prime Minister said: It will be one of the most significant votes that Parliament has held for many years. On it will depend whether we move forward together into a brighter future or open the door to yet more ision and uncertainty.The British people don't want to spend any more time arguing about Brexit.They want a good deal done that fulfils the vote and allows us to come together again as a country.I will take this deal back to the House of Commons, confident we have achieved the best deal available and full of optimism about the future of our country.In Parliament and beyond it, I will make the case for this deal with all my heart and I look forward to that campaign.Mrs May also ruled out a second referendum and refused to comment on her position if parliament rejected her deal.She added: &ldquoI believe there should not be that second referendum, we gave the choice to the British people, they voted, they voted to leave the EU, I think we should now deliver on that.Asked if she would stand down if the deal is voted down in the Commons, she replied: I am focusing on ensuring that I make a case for this deal to MPs and I think the point that Jean-Claude Juncker was making, that's been reiterated by others was that if people think somehow there's another negotiation to be done that's not the case.May said she was not sad about Brexit as the UK and EU would remain friends and neighbours.Asked whether she shared Angela Merkel's sadness at Brexit, Mrs May said: No, but I recognise that others do.I recognise some European leaders are sad at this moment, but also some people back at home in the UK will be sad at this moment.12.10pm update: Brexit deal strenghtens Spain&rsquos position over GibraltarSpanish prime minister Pedro Sanchez says the withdrawal agreement and political declaration agreed between the EU and the UK will strengthen his country's position with Gibraltar.Mr Sanchez said: This puts Spain in a position of strength in negotiations with the United Kingdom over Gibraltar that we have not had until now.12.05pm update: Theresa May press conference&nbspimminentThe Prime Minister to address the media shortly in Brussels&nbsp11.55am update: UK to &lsquoremain friends until the end of days&rsquo with EUEuropean Council President Donald Tusk said during the press conference: Ahead of us is the difficult process of ratification as well as further negotiations.But regardless of how it will all end, one thing is certain: we will remain friends until the end of days. And one day longer.11.45am update: 'Divorce a tragic moment' - Juncker&nbspThe European Commission president said orce is a tragic moment and the UK would not be treated like other third countries.He added: Payments have to be made but the future understanding is one which has to be constructed.I don't think Britain will be a third country like other third countries are third countries.There is, between us, something which has the remainings of love.Jean-Claude Juncker, Donald Tusk and Michel Barnier speak during the press conference in Brussels  (Image: RETUERS)11.28am update: Juncker sends warning to UK parliamentThe President of the European Commission said:&nbspThis is the best deal possible for Britain, this is the best deal possible for Europe.This is the only deal possible.Mr Juncker also sent a message to Brexiteers who want changes to the Prime Ministers deal.He added: &ldquoThose who think if they reject the deals they will get a better deal, will be disappointed within seconds.11.22am update: Brexit news conferenceEuropean Council President Donald Tusk, The President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier are holding a joint press conference in Brussels.11.12am update: Sturgeon slams PM&rsquos public letter and calls on parliament to reject her dealNicola Sturgeon described the letter as desperate and reiterated her calls for alternatives such as staying in the single market and customs union or holding a second referendum.First Minister of Scotland wrote on Twitter: &ldquoI don&rsquot say this lightly, but almost nothing in this desperate letter is true. This is a bad deal, driven by the PM&rsquos self defeating red lines and continual pandering to the right of her own party. Parliament should reject it and back a better alternative - SMCU or #PeoplesVote11.00 update: Brexit deal odds-on to get through ParliamentTheresa May is odds-on to get her Brexit deal through Parliament after the EU approved the withdrawal agreement.Bookmaker William Hill is offering 46 that Mrs May gets enough votes in the House of Commons.William Hill spokesman Rupert Adams, said: &ldquoA fortnight ago it was 110 that Theresa May would fail to get the withdrawal agreement through Parliament.Now it is all change and the odds suggest that Mrs May might just pull this one out of the bag.The withdrawal agreement to be approved by the UK Parliament before 30319: 46 Yes, 1110 NoThe Prime Minster has arrived for talks with leaders of the EU27. (Image: REUTERS)8.05am update: Lithuanian President says there are still &lsquofour scenarios&rsquo available to the UKLithuania's president has stated there are &ldquoat least four possible scenarios that could still happen after EU leaders agree a Brexit deal with the UK.President Dalia Grybauskaite highlighted the possibly for a general election or a peoples vote if the UK parliament vote against Theresa May&rsquos deal.Ms Grybauskaite told reporters as she arrived for the EU summit in Brussels: Everything could happen, at least four possible scenarios could be in place, but it's up to the British side to decide what path to choose.It could be a second vote of the people, it could be new elections, it could be a request for renegotiations, there is at least four scenarios, I calculate.7.51am update: Varadkar confident Europe will approve Brexit dealIreland's premier has said issues remain to be ironed out with the Brexit withdrawal agreement but he is confident that Europe will give it the green-light.Leo Varadkar described the draft deal as the next best thing to the UK staying in the European Union.Mr Varadkar said it protected Ireland's interests and gave people and businesses much needed certainty.He added that there was no other deal on the table.7.30am update: EU stands firm on current dealExpress's Brussels correspondent Joe Barnes has been speaking to key players in Brussels, who have declared the current deal is the only deal.An EU diplomat said: &ldquoThe deal is the deal, it is not going to change.&ldquoWhat can Olly Robbins and Sabine Weyand if they have to sit down on the withdrawal agreement again?&nbsp&ldquoHow can you make changes given each other&rsquos parameters.

story: The Prime Minister travelled to Brussels this weekend to secure agreement with EU leaders over her Brexit deal. But, Theresa May is expected to struggle to get her deal through UK Parliament with the DUP, Labour Party, SNP, Liberal Democrats and several members of her own party saying they will not back the deal. Speaking on Sky News, host Sophy Ridge quizzed the Housing Minister over whether this would lead to a second referendum or even a general election.                BREXIT WARNING: Macron blasts 'French fishing will be PROTECTED'                 Brexit news: EU warns Westminster rebels that May's deal is finalShe said: &ldquoOne of the issues, of course, is that no matter what happens in Brussels here today, the real battle is going to be back in the UK.&ldquoAt the minute, I can&rsquot really see how the numbers add up for that deal to pass through the House of Commons.&ldquoSo if you can&rsquot get it through, what happens next? Do you have a second vote? Do you have an election? Do you have a second referendum? Do you leave with no deal? What happens?Mr Brokenshire replied: &ldquoI think there is a deal that is the best interest of our country, that deals and responds to very clearly the wishes of the British people in referendum.&ldquoTaking back control of our money, our borders, our laws, and giving effect to the referendum result.&ldquoIt is for MPs, of course, to scrutinise this properly. But, if that does not happen then effectively you would be back to square one with more uncertainty, more ision.&ldquoI think it is important that people get behind the Prime Minister, get behind the deal that we see being approved today, and allowing us to move forward as a country, onto all of those things that the British people want us to do, all the domestic priorities and that clear message that we hear time and time again of just &lsquolet&rsquos get on with it&rsquo.&ldquoThat is what we can do here, and&nbspthat is what I want to see Parliament and obviously MPs getting behind as we look to the future.Addressing people who backed Brexit in an open letter released last night, Mrs May made it clear that she believes her deal delivers on the EU referendum result in 2016.Brexit news: Ridge quizzed James Brokenshire over what would happen if May's deal is voted down (Image: SKYNEWS)She wrote: &ldquoIt will honour the result of the referendum. We will take back control of our borders, by putting an end to the free movement of people once and for all. Instead of an immigration system based on where a person comes from, we will build one based on the skills and talents a person has to offer.&ldquoWe will take back control of our money, by putting an end to vast annual payments to the EU. Instead, we will be able to spend British taxpayers&rsquo money on our own priorities, like the extra &pound394 million per week that we are investing in our long-term plan for the NHS.&ldquoAnd we will take back control of our laws, by ending the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice in the UK.&ldquoIn future, our laws will be made, interpreted and enforced by our own courts and legislatures.President of the European Council Donald Tusk confirmed agreement among the EU27 after they met in Brussels on Sunday morning.He said: &ldquoEU27 has endorsed the Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration on the future EU-UK relations.MPs are expected to have a meaningful vote on the Prime Minister&rsquos Brexit deal in December.

title: Brexit news update Theresa May deal Iain Duncan Smith freedom of movement EU
story: The former Conservative Party leader said it would be very, very difficult to support the Prime Minister's Brexit deal arguing far too much has been given to the EU. Mr Duncan Smith revealed Theresa May's deal cedes the right to claim benefits to European citizens warning this would backtrack on the promise of ending freedom of movement.                Brexit summit LIVE: Juncker says he would be 'deeply sad' if British                 How Michael Gove may have SAVED Theresa May's Brexit He told Sky News's Sophy Ridge on Sunday: &ldquoI was looking again at the report and I noticed that in the area where the Government talks about ending freedom of movement, I have to say - having written a paper on this - I don&rsquot really think that&rsquos correct.&ldquoBecause it now talks, buried in there, that there will be social security coordination between us and the EU.&ldquoI think when you strip out the language what that actually means is we are prepared to cede to citizens of the European Union an almost immediate right to claim benefits.&ldquoThis has caused huge damage to many on low incomes who are competing with them when they find that they come in on very, very low salaries and claim all the benefits.Brexit news: Iain Duncan-Smith warns Theresa May's deal will not stop freedom of movement (Image: SKY&bull)&ldquoIt cost for those on low income, for the UK taxpayer, about &pound500 million in the last year on record.&ldquoSo this is a very, very big issue and questions whether we really are going to seriously ending freedom of movement.He added: I don't want to stay in the EU. I campaigned and voted to leave the EU. I don't believe that, so far, this deal delivers on what the British people really voted for, take back control of your borders, your laws, your money.I think it has ceded too much control.I believe the Government needs to go back and say things like 'the backstop, we simply cannot agree it and you must take all of that reference out' and things to do with the Court of Justice.That would make this a better deal, but right now the balance is definitely tilted against this being a deal, I'm afraid, that delivers on what the Government said they would deliver, which is leaving the EU and setting out to be able to do our own trade deals.We won't be able to do our own trade deals if we're bound into the customs union, that is single one of the most important things that people voted for.EU leaders met in Brussels on Sunday for a crunch summit on the Prime Minister's deal.&nbspThe EU27 have shown support for the deal and are expected to vote in favour of it when the deal will return to them after the UK Parliament will give its meaningful&nbspvote.&nbspHowever, Theresa May appears to lack a majority in the House of Commons as Labour, DUP and SNP have all pledged to vote against the deal.

story: Theresa May dodged a question on whether she would resign if her withdrawal agreement fails to get voted in by Parliament, claiming her focus is on &ldquomaking the case for her Brexit deal.During a press conference, one reporter asked: &ldquoYou said today this is the best deal for Britain - we&rsquove heard from other European leaders that this is the only deal that&rsquos on the table as far as there&rsquos no alternative to it.&ldquoIf you can&rsquot get this deal through the House of Commons, and you&rsquove said before that this is not about you, would you feel duty bound to resign?Mrs May gave an awkward chuckle before responding: &ldquoWell you&rsquore right I&rsquove said before it&rsquos not about me, and I will say it again it&rsquos not about me.                Brexit news: Barnier warns UK and EU must &lsquotake responsibilities'                 'Look at the HORROR' Tony Blair GRILLED by Andrew Marr on second vote&ldquoMy focus on the next few weeks is on making the case for this deal, and as you&rsquove heard, I mean President Juncker said, this is the only deal possible.&ldquoThis has been echoed by other European leaders and I think that is, when people come to vote in the House of Commons, they will need to ask themselves about two aspects of this particular.She added: &ldquoThe first is delivering Brexit, I think we have a duty as a House of Commons, as a Parliament, to deliver Brexit.&ldquoThe second question is about what it means for our constituents. As I&rsquove said, the deal that we&rsquove delivered I believe delivers not just on what people wanted when they voted for Brexit, but also does it in a way that protects jobs, protects our security and protects the United Kingdom.Brexit news: Theresa May said the Brexit deal was not about her position as Prime Minister (Image: BBC )The comments come as EU leaders approve the UK's Brexit deal after a 38-minute meeting in Brussels. Donald Tusk wrote on Twitter: &ldquoEU27 has endorsed the Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration on the future EU-UK relations.Jean-Claude Juncker said: &ldquoThis is the best deal possible for Britain, this is the best deal possible for Europe.This is the only deal possible.Mr Juncker also sent a message to Brexiteers who want changes to the Prime Ministers deal, saying: &ldquoThose who think if they reject the deal they will get a better deal, will be disappointed within seconds.But while Mrs May looks like getting the boost she needs from Brussels, mutiny is brewing in London.DUP leader Arlene Foster said there were no circumstances under which her party would vote for the current deal.Appearing on The Andrew Marr Show, Ms Foster said: There is very much a border down the Irish Sea as a result of this and that's way we can't support this deal.Ms Foster said the DUP's confidence and supply agreement with the Conservatives remained live.She again warned that her party would review the arrangement if the Brexit deal gained parliamentary support, but she stopped short of saying she would definitely end the relationship with the Tories in those circumstances.
